headline.main: THE CUBAN MOVEMENT.; Further Particulars of the Preparations for Invading Cuba.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cuban agitation has reawakened the feelings of the country at large, and called from Washington another of those Presidential Proclamations which are expected to posses all the horns and honors of a Pontifical bull.
docs.snippet: The Cuban agitation has reawakened the feelings of the country at large, and called from Washington another of those Presidential Proclamations which are expected to posses all the horns and honors of a Pontifical bull.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: PATRICK HENRY'S SON--The youngest son of PATRICK HENRY died not long ago, poor and alone, in a public-house in Floyd County, va. Recently the tavern people applied to the Overseers of the Poor, for a special grant to indemnify him for boarding, funeral expenses, This was refused on the ground that retrospective appropriations are unauthorized, and that it would be establishing an improper precedent.

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; By Telegraph to the New-York Daily Times. FROM WASHINGTON. The African Slave-Trade. IMPORTANT REPORT IN THE U.S. SENATE. Recommendation to Discontinue the Aftican Squadron. PASSACE OF THE NAVAL BILL. The Cullom and Churchwell Affair--Apologies, & c.. The Gadsden Treaty Amendments Accepted. A $7,000,000 Appropriation Asked for by the President.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following is the Report submitted to the Senate in secret session on the proposal to abrogate the Treaty with Great Britain in regard to the suppression of the Slave-trade on the coast of Africa : [CONFIDENTIAL.]
docs.snippet: The following is the Report submitted to the Senate in secret session on the proposal to abrogate the Treaty with Great Britain in regard to the suppression of the Slave-trade on the coast of Africa : [CONFIDENTIAL.]

docs.lead_paragraph: SINGULAR DEATH.--The Galena (III.) Jeffersonian of the 15th, states that Mr. JOHN A. MOREHEAD, living near Paris, Mo., died last week under singular circumstances. He rose in the morning apparently in his usual health, and after walking about for a short time and partaking of his breakfast, he ordered his negro man to bring a long bench into the house, saying he expected to die soon, and wished to be laid out on the same.

docs.lead_paragraph: We have announced that WM. D. GALLAGHEE, formerly one of the editors of the Cincinnati Gazette, had retired from the conduct of the Louisville Courier. Mr. GALLAGHER has been one of the proprietors of the Courier since January last, and the principal editor for a somewhat longer period.
